title: Part A -1
stimulusHtml: The student response earns one point with an accurate definition of the Green Revolution (as used in the period 1945 to 1985) that mentions both the use of new agricultural practices and the gains in yields and productivity that resulted.
descriptions: The student response fails to include an accurate definition of the Green Revolution (as used in the period 1945 to 1985) that mentions both the use of new agricultural practices and the gains in yields and productivity that resulted.

The student response includes an accurate definition of the Green Revolution (as used in the period 1945 to 1985) that mentions both the use of new agricultural practices and the gains in yields and productivity that resulted.

title: Part A - 2
stimulusHtml: The student response discusses any two of the following principal agricultural practices/technologies can be briefly linked to the Green Revolution: artificial fertilizer; irrigation; insecticides and herbicides; mechanical machinery (e.g., tractors); hybridization; crossbreeding.
descriptions: The student response does not discuss at least two of the following principal agricultural practices/technologies can be briefly linked to the Green Revolution: artificial fertilizer; irrigation; insecticides and herbicides; mechanical machinery (e.g., tractors); hybridization; crossbreeding.

The student response discusses at least two of the following principal agricultural practices/technologies can be briefly linked to the Green Revolution: artificial fertilizer; irrigation; insecticides and herbicides; mechanical machinery (e.g., tractors); hybridization; crossbreeding.

title: Part A - 3
stimulusHtml:
The student response names two appropriate regions to have witnessed an increase in crop yields due to the Green Revolution; include selections from two different columns of the matrix below.

Terms such as "Africa," "Europe," and "U.S.A." do not receive credit. Student responses that incorrectly link a region with a crop do not receive credit. However, although arguably in the same region, student responses earn 2 points for naming India and China as two regions. Countries named within a region also receive 1 point for that region only (for example the response China and Asia receives 1 points)

Countries named within a region also receive 1 point for that region only (for example the response China and Asia receives 1 points)

Terms such as "Africa," "Europe," and "U.S.A." do not receive credit. Student responses that incorrectly link a region with a crop do not receive credit. title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
(4 points)

One point is awarded for correctly identifying a relevant condition, and a second point is awarded for a clear discussion of how the factor operates as a condition. For example, many of the new technologies were costly and could only be secured with inwards investment of capital that in turn flowed to those countries with a stable political regime. Two points for each of two factors yielded 4 points.

There are a wide range of social, political, and cultural conditions that have been necessary for the success of the agricultural practices of the Green Revolution. These include: the availability of credit/banks, money (e.g., international aid, finance, seeds, etc.); political stability; a receptive political environment (outside technology-led innovation); a strong middle class with, for example, independent farmers; a well established market economy; a reliable transportation system; broad cultural acceptance of crops and practices (e.g., "Culturally, the society must be willing to part ways with old-fashioned methods of farming"); an acceptance of the role of Western scientific-based knowledge and the role of education and training within this.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
(4 points)

1 point is awarded for correctly identifying a relevant limit, and a second point for a clear discussion of how the factor operates as a limit. Credit is given for factors that were identified and discussed as causes of (negative) change in the practices of the Green Revolution, as opposed to factors that are negative consequences of the Green Revolution. For example, the assertion "loss of biodiversity" alone scores 1 point. If this was followed by a discussion that such loss of biodiversity has been prompted by trends toward monocropping and the long-term effects of pesticide use (i.e., consequences), no second point was awarded. If the ensuing discussion explained how reductions in biodiversity increased input costs (for example, by increasing runoff and reducing the effectiveness or irrigation systems) then 2 points are awarded.

The economic and ecological limitations on the practices of the Green Revolution include: the growing costs of artificial fertilizer, herbicides, insecticides, fuel; the difficulties experienced by some groups in society (e.g., women) in obtaining credit; the crushing debt load (e.g., faced by farmers, nations, governments, etc.); the operation of commodity markets that may drastically reduce the market price of crops and thus the profits for farmers increasingly dependent upon a limited range of crops; a steady decline in soil quality (soil fertility); water pollution due to runoff; water shortages and drought caused by the reliance on irrigation and the lowering of water tables; potential loss of biodiversity.
